author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

Checkout FHist.jl and StatsBase.jl for histogram.


In general personally used utility packages don't need to get registered. You can ]add by GitHub url to distribute to friends or a different computer of your own

Hi @Moelf — Originally I had intended to submit this functionality as PR to StatsBase, but based on [advice of others there](https://github.com/JuliaStats/StatsBase.jl/pull/760) it seemed better to try to find a home for it as a standalone utility or in a different package. I thought it would be a good learning experience to make my own package for the first time so opted to try going that route, which is why I've done this. This is a really common utility used by a lot of people in academia (I'm an astrophysics PhD student), and things like this that are missing from Julia are a big barrier to entry for some of my colleagues. You are correct that some of this functionality is already possible with existing packages, but this way is much faster (>10x speed-up compared to using the StatsBase histogram method, for example). This is detailed more in my original linked PR if you would like to read more there. I had hoped I could continue adding commonly used routines that exist in other languages (Python, IDL, etc.) but that do not yet exist in Julia to this new package as I think that would be a useful tool for myself + others in my field, but if you think that's not worth having as a package I suppose I can distribute ad-hoc internally.

I'm thinking now it might be better if this was just named `binnedStatistic` and only did this one equivalent operation to SciPy to better follow the guidelines (no amalgamations of utility functions), so I'll delete this repo and re-submit later. If you think this could be integrated into FHist.jl @Moelf let me know and happy to go that route as well!
This should be closed / deleted in favor of re-submission under new name / description (https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/54800)

if I'm understanding correctly, the "statistics" is just a function you apply bin-by-bin right? effectively you're keeping track of a "statistics metric" for all the data ever went into that bin, while also making a histogram.

this is an interesting application, in FHist.jl the "statistics" we choose is sum of weight^2, because it gives you the error on the final bin count (gaussian approximation to the poission statistics)
Yes exactly @Moelf. If you think this is something we could roll into FHist.jl let me know and I would be happy to help!
